objectID: notes/A Statistical Analysis to Women College Basketball 2024.html
href: notes/A Statistical Analysis to Women College Basketball 2024.html
title: A Statistical Analysis to Women College Basketball 2024
text:
March Madness is nearly upon us! Before filling out my beloved bracket, I wanted to dig into the data to better understand how Women‚Äôs College Basketball teams perform. Unlike Men‚Äôs College Basketball though, statistical analysis on the Women‚Äôs game is sparse. This created a great opportunity to dig into the data.
Since analysis for the Men‚Äôs game is widely available and well documented, I applied some of the most popular methodologies to basic team stats for the Women‚Äôs game. In this article, I‚Äôll focus on calculating: 1. Pace 2. Four Factors 3. Offensive and Defensive ratings
With these stats, we‚Äôre can go into March Madness better understanding the strengths of teams, predict the win probability of matchups, and identify the games that might be most exciting.
The data used here comes from Sports Reference. While some of the data we be calculating could be pulled directly from Sports Reference‚Äôs Advance Stats, we still calculate each stats since some of the method may deviate slightly.
In many of the analysis, we‚Äôll also compare Sports Reference‚Äôs Simple Rating System (SRS) with the stats that we calculate. The Overall SRS, ‚Äútakes into account average point differential and strength of schedule‚Äù, where zero is average and a high positive number signals a strong team.

Pace / Possessions
Let‚Äôs start off by calculating ‚ÄúPace‚Äù. Pace is the number of possessions the team has over the course of the game. Teams with more possession generally like to play with a faster paced game where the ball is changes hands more often and there‚Äôs more movement up and down the court.
Pace is calculated as:
Field¬†Goal¬†Attempts¬†-¬†Offensive¬†Rebound¬†+¬†Turnovers¬†+¬†0.475¬†*¬†Free¬†Throw¬†Attempts
Other formulas for calculating pace may use a different free throw multiplier. I‚Äôve chosen to use the method by KenPom, one of leaders in Men‚Äôs college basketball analysis.
The average pace for all Women‚Äôs D1 College teams is 70.97.



Pasted image 20240321154820.png


For reference, the Men‚Äôs College average pace is generally the same at around 70 per 40 min[^1], while the WNBA average pace is 82.2 per 40 min period[^2] and the NBA average pace is 99.3 per 40 min period[^3].
The correlation between Pace and the Overall SRS of a team is very slight slope indicating that teams with higher overall SRS will on average potentially push the game to include a few more possessions.



Pasted image 20240321155153.png


We‚Äôll later use pace to estimate the number of possessions in a game which when used with offensive and defensive rating can help us predict the win % of a game.
Next, let‚Äôs calculate Dean Oliver‚Äôs four factor of basketball success. Dean Oliver‚Äôs book ‚ÄúBasketball on Paper‚Äù has been equated to as the moneyball of Basketball. He summarizes the success of a team based on shooting the ball well, avoiding turnovers, getting second chances to score the ball with offensive rebounds, and getting to the foul line.
To calculate each of these factors, I‚Äôll again use KenPom‚Äôs formula‚Äôs. For simplicity, we also use the average per game stats across the entire season.


Shooting
For shooting, we‚Äôll calcuate the effective field goal percentage (eFG%). The eFG% weights 3 pointers made 50% more than other field goals made. (Field¬†Goals¬†Made¬†+¬†0.5¬†*¬†3-pointers¬†Made)¬†/¬†Field¬†Goals¬†Attempted



Pasted image 20240322115305.png


With the shooting prodigy of Caitlin Clark, it‚Äôs no suprise that Iowa currently has highest effective field goal percentage. Not only are they ranked 1st for 3 points made but they‚Äôre also ranked 2nd for field goals made.
Interestingly, UConn a ‚Äúsmall‚Äô team with an average height of 6ft currently, (when we account for only their active and not injuried players), has both a relatively high effective field goal % but also they‚Äôre opponents seem to have a harder time shooting against them compared to other great shooting teams. This just adds to the many reason why I‚Äôm extremely excited to see a UConn/Iowa matchup in the Final Four.
When we plot the strengths of the team against their eFG%, we see a strong correlation between great teams and their ability to shoot the ball. 


Rebounding
On the offensive rebound end, we‚Äôll first need to calculate the opponent‚Äôs defensive rebound since that‚Äôs a rebound made by the opponent when the team was on offense. To calculate the offensive rebound %, we‚Äôll use the formula: Offensive¬†Rebounds¬†/¬†(Offensive¬†Rebounds¬†+¬†Opponent‚Äôs¬†Defensive¬†Rebounds)
Unlike other calculated stats that are labelled with a ‚Äúoff‚Äù for offense and ‚Äúdef‚Äù for defense, I‚Äôve label offensive rebounds when the team is on defense as ‚ÄúOpponent Offensive Rebound %‚Äù to minimize any confusion.



Pasted image 20240322170814.png


Louisiana State (LSU) leads this stat which should be no surprise since Angel Reese is currently the 2nd leading rebounder and she favors the inside shot. Lauren Betts (UCLA) and Kamilla Cardoso (USC), both 6‚Äô 7‚Äù inside the paint shooters also help explain UCLA and USC showing on this list. What was interesting though is that although Stanford is ranked 7th in total rebounds they are ranked only 12th for offensive rebound %. My hunch is that since Cameron Brink has such a great outside shot, she‚Äôs not around to assist with the offensive rebounds.


Turnovers & Free Throws
Lastly, we have turnover % is measured by Turnovers / Possessions, keep in mind that pace is the average number of possessions per game.



Pasted image 20240322171633.png


And free throw rates, which is the number of times the team gets to the free throw line measured as Free¬†Throws¬†Attempts¬†/¬†Field¬†Goal¬†Attempts.



Pasted image 20240322171714.png




Relationship of Four Factors
Once we have all four factors calculated, both for offense and defense, we can see how each factor impacts their SRS rating.



Pasted image 20240322172021.png


What we can see here is that there‚Äôs a very strong correlation between highly rated teams and their offensive effective field goal %, great teams have a high percentage of effective field goals. There‚Äôs also correlation between highly rated teams with a low turnover %, great teams hold on to the ball. The relationship between offensive rebound % and offensive free throw rates appear to be there but might not make as much of a difference though.
The story on the defensive four factor side is a bit harder to decipher. While we can see. that better teams will limit their opponents field goals and their opponent‚Äôs ability to grab offensive rebounds turnover % and free throw rates appear a bit more scattered.



Pasted image 20240322172918.png


With the four factors, we can calculate the offensive and defensive efficiency of the teams. The offensive and defensive efficiency tell us the number of points scored or allowed per 100 possessions.
There are multiple ways to derive the offensive and defensive efficiency of a team based on the four factors. While Kenpom doesn‚Äôt publish the regression he uses, I was able to find CBB Analytic‚Äôs model.[^5]
Predicted Offensive/Defensive efficiency = 32.333 + 1.55*eFG% + 0.47*ORB% - 1.55*TOV% + 0.19*FTA Rate
This model was likely built using only data from the Men‚Äôs Basketball game so we know there‚Äôs some margin of error introduced. In the future, I hope to validate the accuracy of this regression and derive our own regression based previous game data. However for now we just plugged in our values to get an initial offensive and defensive efficiency.
By plotting these values on to 4 quandrants that are split based on the median offensive and defensive efficiency, we can see an overview of the teams with the strongest offense and defense.



Pasted image 20240322174452.png


For the purpose of this chart, I‚Äôve chosen to only display the top 20% of teams based on their Overall SRS. However, since March Maddess selection is not based on Overall SRS, not all teams playing in March Madness is on this chart and not all teams on this chart are playing in March Maddess.
And there you have it, an introduction to some of the teams playing over the next few weeks. March Madness can be madness though and anything could happen.
This statistical analysis was all done in Google Colab located here, if you are interested in digging in and playing around with it yourself.
[^1] https://kenpom.com/blog/national-efficiency/ [^2] https://herhoopstats.com/stats/wnba/league/ [^3] https://www.nba.com/stats/teams/advanced?dir=-1&sort=PACE&PerMode=Per40 [^4] https://kenpom.com/blog/four-factors/ [^5] https://thepowerrank.com/cbb-analytics/

title: Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
text:
Code
# Create dataframe for offensive and defensive team stats
team_stats = pd.merge(raw_stats, raw_opponent_stats, on="School", how="inner")
team_stats.columns = team_stats.columns.str.replace('_x', '')

team_stats = team_stats[['School', 'Overall_SRS', 'Overall_SOS', 'Overall_W', 'Overall_L',
                         'Team_FG', 'Team_FGA', 'Team_3P', 'Team_3PA',  'Team_FTA', 'Team_ORB', 'Team_TRB', 'Team_TOV',
                         'Opponent_FG', 'Opponent_FGA', 'Opponent_3P', 'Opponent_3PA',  'Opponent_FTA', 'Opponent_ORB', 'Opponent_TRB', 'Opponent_TOV']].copy()

# Set datatype
team_stats = team_stats.astype({
    'Overall_SRS': 'float',
    'Overall_SOS': 'float',
    'Overall_W': 'int',
    'Overall_L': 'int'
})

# Cast all other columns to float
cast_to_float = team_stats.columns[5:]
team_stats[cast_to_float] = team_stats[cast_to_float].astype(float)

team_stats.dtypes

# Divide teams into SRS percentile
bins = [0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.8, 1]
labels = ['Bottom 25%', '25th-50th %', '50th-80th %', 'Top 20%']

team_stats['Pct_Group'] = pd.qcut(team_stats['Overall_SRS'], q=bins, labels=labels)

title: Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
section: Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
text:
Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
Unlike Men‚Äôs College Basketball, statistical analysis on the Women‚Äôs game is relatively sparse. Since analysis for the Men‚Äôs game is widely available and well documented, I‚Äôve applied some of the most popular methodologies to basic team stats for the Women‚Äôs game to better understand how strongly corralated the four factors are with the teams simple rating system, measure the offsive and defensive efficiency of each team, and visualize the strengths (and weaknesses) of each team. Let‚Äôs dive in!

title: Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
text:
Four Factors of Basketball
The Four Factors designed by Dean Oliver in ‚ÄúBasketball on Paper‚Äù is considered the moneyball of Basketball to measure a team‚Äôs success. While these stats can be found calculated in Sports Reference‚Äôs Advanced School Stats, we‚Äôll calculated them to see how they correlate with the teams simple rating system then use the four factors to measure the offensive and defensive efficiency of each team.
These four factors are:
Shooting the ball well measured by effective Field Goal % (eFG%)


Code
# Calculate both offensive and defensive effective field goal percentage
team_stats['Calc_Off_eFG%'] = (team_stats['Team_FG'] + 0.5 * team_stats['Team_3P']) / team_stats['Team_FGA']
team_stats['Calc_Def_eFG%'] = (team_stats['Opponent_FG'] + 0.5 * team_stats['Opponent_3P']) / team_stats['Opponent_FGA']


The effective field goal % captures the teams ability to shoot the ball. Because at the end of the game, the team with the most points wins. This is calculated as Field Goals Made + 0.5 * 3-pointers Made) / Field Goals Attempted. Unlike FG%, this calculation adds 50% more credit for 3-pointers made, since they are worth more points.
** Avoiding turnovers - Turnover % **


Code
# Calculate Pace or Possessions
team_stats['Pace'] = team_stats['Team_FGA'] - team_stats['Team_ORB'] + team_stats['Team_TOV'] + (0.475 * team_stats['Team_FTA'] )

# Calculate Turnover %
team_stats['Calc_Off_TOV%'] = team_stats['Team_TOV'] / team_stats['Pace']
team_stats['Calc_Def_TOV%'] = team_stats['Opponent_TOV'] / team_stats['Pace']


Giving the ball away too often is a surefire way to lose a game. What percentage of possessions end in a turnover?
Turnover % = Turnovers / Possessions
Second changes to score: Offensive rebound % 


Code
# Create the defensive rebound column
team_stats['Team_DRB'] = team_stats['Team_TRB'] - team_stats['Team_ORB']
team_stats['Opponent_DRB'] = team_stats['Opponent_TRB'] - team_stats['Opponent_ORB']

# Calculate offensive rebound %
team_stats['Calc_ORB%'] = team_stats['Team_ORB'] / (team_stats['Team_ORB'] + team_stats['Opponent_DRB'])
team_stats['Calc_Opp_ORB%'] = team_stats['Opponent_ORB'] / (team_stats['Opponent_ORB'] + team_stats['Team_DRB'])


Offensive rebounds are a second change at scoring. So of the total rebounds happening while a team is on offense, how many are the offensive team getting them.
Offensive Rebounding % = Offensive Rebounds / (Offensive Rebounds + Opponent‚Äôs Defensive Rebounds)
Getting to the foul line: Free throw rate


Code
team_stats['Calc_Off_FTR'] = team_stats['Team_FTA'] / team_stats['Team_FGA']
team_stats['Calc_Def_FTR'] = team_stats['Opponent_FTA'] / team_stats['Opponent_FGA']


Free throws are yet another attempt to score. So getting fouled
Free Throw Rate = Free Throws Attempts / Field Goal Attempts

Relationship of Four Factors with Overall SRS
Once each of these metrics has been calculated, let‚Äôs evaulate the impact each metric has on the overall simple rating system of the team.


Code
# Set up the figure with four subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))  # 2x2 grid

off_four_factors = team_stats[['School', 'Overall_SRS', 'Calc_Off_eFG%', 'Calc_ORB%', 'Calc_Off_TOV%', 'Calc_Off_FTR']]

# List of offensive factors
offensive_factors = ['Calc_Off_eFG%', 'Calc_ORB%', 'Calc_Off_TOV%', 'Calc_Off_FTR']

# Loop through the factors and plot each one against 'Overall_SRS'
for ax, factor in zip(axes.flatten(), offensive_factors):
    sns.regplot(
        data=off_four_factors,
        x=factor,
        y='Overall_SRS',
        ax=ax,
        scatter_kws={'s': 10},
        line_kws={'color': 'red', 'linewidth': 0.8}
    )
    ax.set_title(f'Relationship between {factor} and Overall_SRS')

plt.suptitle('Impact of Offensive Four Factors on Overall SRS', y=1.02)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()











Code
# Set up the figure with four subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, figsize=(12, 10))  # 2x2 grid

def_four_factors = team_stats[['School', 'Overall_SRS', 'Calc_Def_eFG%', 'Calc_Opp_ORB%', 'Calc_Def_TOV%', 'Calc_Def_FTR']]

# List of defensive factors
defensive_factors = ['Calc_Def_eFG%', 'Calc_Opp_ORB%', 'Calc_Def_TOV%', 'Calc_Def_FTR']

# Loop through the factors and plot each one against 'Overall_SRS'
for ax, factor in zip(axes.flatten(), defensive_factors):
    sns.regplot(
        data=def_four_factors,
        x=factor,
        y='Overall_SRS',
        ax=ax,
        scatter_kws={'s': 10},
        line_kws={'color': 'red', 'linewidth': 0.8}
    )
    ax.set_title(f'Relationship between {factor} and Overall_SRS')

plt.suptitle('Impact of Defensive Four Factors on Overall SRS', y=1.02)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()









In all calculations, I use per game average since as a basketball fan, it allows me to reason about the data and catch mistakes easier. For example, if free throw attemps is 78, I‚Äôm able to recognize and issue witih my data. To increase accuracy calculations could be done on a per game basis before averaged out.
Sources: https://kenpom.com/blog/four-factors/

title: Statistical Analysis of 2024 Women‚Äôs College Basketball
text:
Offensive & Defensive Efficiency
In order for us to measure the offensive and defensive efficiency of each team, we‚Äôll first calculate these stats for each team, this is their offense. For defense, we‚Äôll calculate how well their opponents do in each of these stats when playing against them.

team_stats['Calc_Off_Eff'] = 32.333 + 1.55 * team_stats['Calc_Off_eFG%'] * 100 \
                                    + 0.47 * team_stats['Calc_ORB%'] * 100 \
                                    - 1.55 * team_stats['Calc_Off_TOV%'] * 100 \
                                    + 0.19 * team_stats['Calc_Off_FTR'] * 100

sorted_df = team_stats.sort_values(by='Calc_Off_Eff', ascending=False)
sorted_df[['School', 'Overall_SRS', 'Calc_Off_Eff', 'Calc_Off_eFG%', 'Calc_ORB%', 'Calc_Off_TOV%', 'Calc_Off_FTR']].head(10)

Code
top_20 = team_stats[team_stats['Pct_Group'] == "Top 20%"]
top20_4f = top_20[['School', 'Overall_SRS', 'Pace',
                   'Calc_Off_Eff', 'Calc_Off_eFG%', 'Calc_ORB%', 'Calc_Off_TOV%', 'Calc_Off_FTR',
                   'Calc_Def_Eff', 'Calc_Def_eFG%', 'Calc_Opp_ORB%', 'Calc_Def_TOV%', 'Calc_Def_FTR']].copy()


fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12,12))

# Assign values
labels = top20_4f.School
x = top20_4f.Calc_Off_Eff
y = top20_4f.Calc_Def_Eff

# Set mean
ax.axvline(x=x.mean(), linestyle='--', color='red')
ax.axhline(y=y.mean(), linestyle='--', color='red')

# Plot data
for x0, y0, label in zip(x, y, labels):
  plt.text(x0, y0, label, fontsize=8, ha='right', va='bottom')

plt.scatter(x, y)

# Add grid
ax.grid(zorder=0, alpha=0.4)
ax.set_axisbelow(True)

ax.set_xlim(85, 120)
ax.set_ylim(98, 70)

# Add labels and text
ax.set_xlabel('Adjusted Offensive Efficiency')
ax.set_ylabel('Adjusted Defensive Efficiency')

ax.text(0.99, 0.01, 'Better Offense\nWorst Defense',
        verticalalignment='bottom', horizontalalignment='right',
        transform=ax.transAxes,
        color='green', fontsize=12)

ax.text(0.99, 0.99, 'Better Offense\nBetter Defense',
        verticalalignment='top', horizontalalignment='right',
        transform=ax.transAxes,
        color='green', fontsize=12)

ax.text(0.01, 0.99, 'Worst Offense\nBetter Defense',
        verticalalignment='top', horizontalalignment='left',
        transform=ax.transAxes,
        color='green', fontsize=12)

ax.text(0.01, 0.01, 'Worst Offense\nWorst Defense',
        verticalalignment='bottom', horizontalalignment='left',
        transform=ax.transAxes,
        color='green', fontsize=12)

ax.set_title('2024 Women\'s NCAA Basketball Tiers')


Text(0.5, 1.0, "2024 Women's NCAA Basketball Tiers")
etsaii










Relationship of Four Factors
Once we have all four factors calculated, both for offense and defense, we can see how each factor impacts their SRS rating.
In many of the analysis, we‚Äôll also compare Sports Reference‚Äôs Simple Rating System (SRS) with the stats that we calculate. The Overall SRS, ‚Äútakes into account average point differential and strength of schedule‚Äù, where zero is average and a high positive number signals a strong team.
Data Sources: Sports Reference: https://www.sports-reference.com/cbb/seasons/women/2024-ratings.html Massey Rating: https://masseyratings.com/cbw/ncaa-d1/ratings Sokol‚Äôs LRMC ratings: https://www2.isye.gatech.edu/~jsokol/lrmcW/ Moore‚Äôs ratings: https://sonnymoorepowerratings.com/w-basket.htm

title: Elaine Tsai
text:
Previously a startup product manager at Twilio, Postmates, and RevOps. Now a full-time mom, building and vibe-coding one nap at a time.
I seek experiences that are novel, challenging, and fun from shipping innovative tech products to . I‚Äôm driven by curiosity, motivated by action, and have an evergrowing list of ideas and dreams.
I‚Äôm a New Yorker at heart, raised in an American bubble in Taipei, Taiwan. Currently, I reside in Brooklyn, NY.

title: Elaine Tsai
text:
Education
Bowdoin College | B.A in Economics | Brunswick, ME

title: BK Baby and Me
text:
As a new parent in Brooklyn, I got tired of tracking Baby and Me activities across different sites then forgetting about them. To solve this, I built BK Baby and Me a single-page React app that displays all the weekly activities in one clean, filterable view. Then allows me to export the events to iCal for easy calendar integration.



BK Baby and Me app screenshot


üîó View app | GitHub repo
